description: From Latin tersus (“clean, cleansed, rubbed or wiped off; neat, spruce; terse”), perfect passive participle of tergō, tergeō (“to clean, cleanse, rub, wipe, wipe off”), from Proto-Indo-European *terh₁- (“to rub; to turn”).

entries.meaning: (by extension) Of speech or style: brief, concise, to the point.
examples: Synonyms: concise, succinct; see also Thesaurus:concise
Antonyms: prolix, verbose, wordy; see also Thesaurus:verbose

entries.meaning: (by extension) Of manner or speech: abruptly or brusquely short; curt.
(obsolete) Burnished, polished; fine, smooth; neat, spruce. [from early 17th c.]
